Allied deterrence—primarily through visible US, Japanese, and partner military exercises and diplomatic signaling—is credited with raising the anticipated costs for Beijing to prohibitive levels. Intelligence and open source consensus points instead to the likelihood of continued gray-zone escalation or possible moves against peripheral islands, not a main-island assault meeting the resolution criteria (1,000+ PLA troops landed or invasion verified by AP/NYT).

Area and China-policy specialists further reduce the near-term risk, pointing to the lack of acute domestic political pressure on Xi Jinping to justify immediate war and an evident continued preference for incremental, coercive tactics rather than a high-risk campaign. Across all perspectives, the only significant caveat is the small, nonzero risk of a strategic shock or miscalculation—such as a Taiwanese independence declaration or a dramatic, destabilizing black swan event. However, all agree no such trigger is currently apparent.
